Details: A package for filtering splice junctions extracted from noisy long read alignments generated using minimap2.
Underlying_algorithms: Uses junction alignment metrics and logistic regression on splice junction sequences to classify splice junctions as genuine or spurious
Underlying_assumptions: Assumes a canonical intron motif of GT/AG or GC/AG by default (although this can be changed using CLI options)
Strengths_weaknesses: The filtered spliced junctions can be used to perform second pass alignment with minimap2, feeding in the junctions using the --junc-bed flag.
Overall_performance: For simulated nanopore direct RNA sequencing reads, two pass alignment increased the percentage of correctly aligned spliced reads by >15% for Arabidopsis samples and >20% for human samples

BugSeq is an online platform enabling end-to-end, rapid and highly accurate analysis for long-read sequencing data avaialble at https://bugseq.com/free
Underlying_algorithms: Demultiplexing with G493;Quality control with prinseq-lite;Alignment against RefSeq with minimap2;Pathoscope;Calculate lowest common ancestor;NanoCLUST;Assembly with metaFlye
Underlying_assumptions: BugSeq takes raw sequencing data in FASTQ, FAST5 or FASTA format. Analysis is automatically tailored based on the format of the input data, and an intelligent detection of experimental design (eg. metagenomic, 16S, ITS or other).
Strengths_weaknesses: BugSeq enables a fully automated end-to-end analysis for microbial sequencing data, including basecalling, quality control, taxonomic classification, assembly, microbial typing, consensus generation and antimicrobial resistance prediction. BugSeq version 1 is more accurate than all metagenomic classifiers for long-read sequencing data while maintaining competitive or superior run times.
Overall_performance: BugSeq (F1=0.91-0.95) offers better read classification than MetaMaps (F1=0.89-0.94) in a fraction of the time. BugSeq significantly improves on the accuracy of Centrifuge (F1=0.79-0.93) while offering competitive run times. We apply BugSeq to metagenomic sequencing of 41 samples from patients with lower respiratory tract infections and show that it produces greater concordance with microbiological culture and qPCR compared with What is In My Pot analysis.

Detect overlaps in high-noise sequences using MHAP. Generate corrected sequence consensus. Trim corrected sequences. Assemble trimmed corrected sequences. Takes all-vs-all read self-mappings (typically by minimap) as input and outputs an assembly graph in the GFA format. Different from mainstream assemblers, miniasm does not have a consensus step. It simply concatenates pieces of read sequences to generate the final contig sequences. Thus, the per-base error rate is similar to the raw input reads.

DraftPolisher is a tool for fast polishing of draft sequences. DraftPolisher can produce an improved consensus sequence for a draft genome assembly (or any draft sequence assembly) by using a reference genome and a reference database of sequences (by which the frequences of a defined k-mer, representative of each mismatch, will be evaluated) both in FASTA format.
DraftPolisher is designed for the polishing of draft sequences. Two different releases of the tool are present: DraftPolisher.py and DraftPolisher_cov.py. The "cov" release (i.e. coverage release) takes into account also the coverage of the sequences from the reference database used for the polishing. The "cov" release was designed based on the SPAdes assembling output file format, where the coverage value is reported in the last part of the sequences IDs, so if using this version of the tool take care of the reference sequences file format (see SPAdes output format for more details).Three files are required by the tool: the query sequence to polish, a reference sequence, a reference database of sequences and the size of the k-mer to use to perform the polishing (we suggest k-mer size = 8). In "Test" folder data for testing the tool are available.
Underlying_algorithms: The tool performs a first alignment against a reference sequence (e.g. reference genome) and identify all the missmatches. After, each of the missmatches is evaluated considering a reference database of high quality sequences ( provided by the user). These could be whatever sequences in fasta format. The polishing of the draft sequence is performed considering the frequency of kmers of defined size (default is 16 bp) around each of the missmatches. if the frequency for the mismatches and the reference sequence is the same the missmach is kept, for a conservative approach.
Underlying_assumptions: The reference database of sequences provided, is assumed to be in average a good representation of the correct sequences. This tool is ment for short gaps or mismatches. The tool was designed to use SPAdes tool assembling output as reference database of sequences but can be easly adapted for other sequence database formats.
Strengths_weaknesses: The tool is very fast using MinION data but cannot be used with fastq files (only fasta)
Overall_performance: For MinION assembling data the tool requires few minutes to generate a better quality assembly

Details: Elongating long read assembler
Underlying_algorithms: 1) You provide it with a starter. It can be a contig from some other assembly or just a random read. 2) It maps reads to the 3' end of the starter. 3) It calculates a consensus of reads that overhang the 3' end and extends the starter. 4) It goes to the step "2)".
Strengths_weaknesses: A useful feature of Elloreas is that if it sees several alternative extensions for the contig, it will tell the user about their existence and give their sequences too.

Error corrects ONT transcript reads
Underlying_algorithms: isONcorrect uses paired minimizer anchors and formulates the error correction problem as a Weighted Interval Scheduling (WIS) problem that is solved exactly. Intervals chosen in the optimal WIS solution are corrected separately and the corrected interval is substituted back into the original region of the read. A strenght with isONcorrect is that it is designed to leverage from shader exons between different isoforms, increasing the effective coverage for correction.
Underlying_assumptions: Assumes reads are clustered into genes with a clustering algorithm such as isONclust or CARNAC-LR.
Overall_performance: Assumes reads are clustered into genes with a clustering algorithm such as isONclust or CARNAC-LR.

Underlying_algorithms: LAMSA takes takes the advantage of the rareness of SVs to implement a specifically designed two-step strategy. That is, LAMSA initially splits the read into relatively long fragments and co-linearly align them to solve the small variations or sequencing errors, and mitigate the effect of repeats. The alignments of the fragments are then used for implementing a sparse dynamic programming (SDP)-based split alignment approach to handle the large or non-co-linear variants.

Underlying_algorithms: LJA consists of three modules each of which addresses a computational challenge that is unique for HiFI reads: (i) jumboDBG module for de Bruijn graph construction for arbitrarily large values of k; (ii) mowerDBG module for almost perfect error correction and (iii) multiDBG module for using variable values of k in different parts of the genome and using the full length of HiFi reads for repeat resolution. In addition, since LJA compresses homopolymers in reads to avoid frequent errors in homopolymers, LJA uses LJApolisher tool for uncompressing and polishing final contigs.

PALMER detects non-reference MEI events (LINE, Alu and SVA) and other insertions, by using the indexed reference-aligned BAM files from long-read technology as inputs. It uses the track from RepeatMasker to pre-mask the portions of reads that aligned to these repeats, defines the significant characteristics of MEIs (TSD motifs, 5' inverted sequence, 3' transduction sequence, polyA-tail), and reports sequences for each insertion event.
Strengths_weaknesses: By using PALMER on the long-read sequencing data, we can identify approximately 50% more MEIs that missed by the standard short-read whole-genome sequencing technology, most of which are siting in the reference repetitive regions.

Strengths_weaknesses: Reasons to use Rebaler: You want to reassemble/polish an assembly with long reads, using a reference assembly to guide the large-scale structure; You don't want the reference assembly's basecalls to influence the basecalls in your new assembly. Reasons to not use Rebaler: You expect there to be structural differences between your reference genome and your sequenced reads. Rebaler is built on the assumption that the genome structure is the same, only bases differ; You want to polish an assembly using the same long reads you used to make the assembly. Rebaler might work for this, but simply using Racon on its own is probably better

Underlying_algorithms: 1. rMETL extracts the chimerically aligned parts of the reads which have split alignment, large clippings and/or large indels; 2. rMETL clusters the chimerically aligned read parts in predefined rules to infer a set of putative MEI sites as candidates; 3. rMETL realigns the clustered read parts to the consensus sequences of Alu, L1 and SVA families with a well-tuned aligner; 4. rMETL investigates the realignment results to find out the evidence to call MEIs as well as filter false positive candidates.
Strengths_weaknesses: rMETL has good ability to detect MEIs but might fail at the incorrect realignment of read parts or the lack of supporting reads.
Overall_performance: Benchmarking results of simulated and real datasets demonstrate that rMETL enables to handle the complex signals to discover MEIs sensitively. It is suited to produce high-quality MEI callsets in many genomics studies.

SneakySnake:snake: is the first and the only pre-alignment filtering algorithm that works efficiently and fast on modern CPU, FPGA, and GPU architectures. It greatly (by more than two orders of magnitude) expedites sequence alignment calculation for both short and long reads.
Underlying_algorithms: The key idea of SneakySnake is to reduce the approximate string matching (ASM) problem to the single net routing (SNR) problem in VLSI chip layout. In the SNR problem, we are interested in only finding the optimal path that connects two terminals with the least routing cost on a special grid layout that contains obstacles. The SneakySnake algorithm quickly solves the SNR problem and uses the found optimal path to decide whether performing sequence alignment is necessary. Reducing the ASM problem into SNR also makes SneakySnake efficient to implement for modern high-performance computing architectures (CPUs, GPUs, and FPGAs).
Overall_performance: SneakySnake significantly improves the accuracy of pre-alignment filtering by up to four orders of magnitude compared to the state-of-the-art pre-alignment filters, Shouji, GateKeeper, and SHD. Using short sequences, SneakySnake accelerates Edlib (state-of-the-art implementation of Myers bit-vector algorithm) and Parasail (sequence aligner with configurable scoring function), by up to 37.7x and 43.9x (>12x on average), respectively, without requiring hardware acceleration, and by up to 413x and 689x (>400x on average), respectively, using hardware acceleration. Using long sequences, SneakySnake accelerates Parasail by up to 979x (140.1x on average). SneakySnake also accelerates the sequence alignment of minimap2, a state-of-the-art read mapper, by up to 6.83x (4.67x on average) and 64.1x (17.1x on average) using short and long sequences, respectively, and without requiring hardware acceleration. As SneakySnake does not replace sequence alignment, users can still configure the aligner of their choice for different scoring functions, surpassing most existing efforts that aim to accelerate sequence alignment.

Strengths_weaknesses: Can make informative plots, find differentially expressed genes and transcripts, find isoform-switching genes, and discover novel exon skipping and intron retention events.

Details: Synteny and Rearrangement Identifier
A small python program to simulate a real-time Nanopore sequencing run based on previous experiment.
Estimates poly(A) tail lengths in Oxford Nanopore RNA and DNA reads
A research software for training models for basecalling Oxford Nanopore reads
License: Oxford Nanopore Technologies, Ltd. Public License Version 1.0

Details: Transcription aware (tailored for RNA-Seq) hybrid long read correction tool
Single-cell analysis workflows for double phosphoramidite barcode and UMI Correction (scBUC-seq)
Technology agnostic long read analysis pipeline for transcriptomes
Transcriptome annotation using long read data via modular tools.
Detection of tandem repeat expansions from long reads
Tool for assessing/improving assembly quality in extra-long tandem repeats
Overall_performance: TandemTools software that includes the TandemMapper tool for mapping reads to ETRs and the TandemQUAST tool for polishing ETR assemblies and their quality assessment

Details: For correcting and aligning long reads with/without a second generation reads, transcript clustering, novel and full-length splice isoform detection, and identification and analysis of polyAdenylation (poly(A)) and alternative poly(A) (APA).
A computational framework for the analysis of the functional impact of differential splicing
A non-reference transposable element (TE) detector from long read sequencing data

A gap-closing software tool that uses error-prone long reads generated by third-generation-sequence techniques (Pacbio, Oxford Nanopore, etc.) or preassembled contigs to fill N-gap in the genome assembly
A tandem repeat detection and consensus calling tool which is designed for tandemly repeated long-read sequence (INC-seq, R2C2, NanoAmpli-Seq)
Correct misassemblies using linked reads
Predict plasmids from uncorrected long read data
Detects, assembles and annotates insertions via long-read alignments
ToFU enables generation of de novo transcriptome from PacBio reads
DEPRECATED:: A suite of tools primarily for the identification of modified nucleotides
QC for ONT data
Variant-aware correction of indels, mismatches and splice junctions in long-read transcripts
Simulates reads with technical and transcriptome-specific features learnt from nanopore RNA-sequncing data
A tool for predicting transcript sequences with long reads
A tandem repeats profiler for long-read sequencing data
License: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0
Overall_performance: The method can identify repetitive regions in sequencing data without a prior knowledge of their motifs or locations and resolve repeat multiplicity and period size in a haplotype-specific manner

Details: Trycycler is a tool for generating consensus long-read assemblies for bacterial genomes. I.e. if you have multiple long-read assemblies for the same isolate, Trycycler can combine them into a single assembly that is better than any of your inputs
Target sequencing discovery using long reads
Assembler for long reads
A tool for spliced alignment of long transcriptomic reads to a genome, guided by a database of exon annotations
Pipeline for the detection and annotation of transcripts from long-read sequences
Generates and processes accurate consensus sequences
Maps raw nanopore signals from fast5 files to large DNA references
Assemble Illumina (uses spades), ONT, PacBio (uses miniasm+Racon) or hybrid data for bacterial genomes
Viral variant calling and denovo assembly using nanopore and illumina reads
variation graph data structures, interchange formats, alignment, genotyping, and variant calling methods
A haplotype-aware structural variants simulator for short, long and linked reads
License: GNU Lesser General Public License v3.0

Details: Read Mapping on Genome Variation Graphs
A long-read mapping and structural variant calling via dual-mode alignment
Underlying_algorithms: Leverages the computed normalized edit distance of the mapped reads via e.g. minimap2 to identify poorly aligned reads and realigns them using the more accurate yet computationally more expensive long read mapper (NGMLR)
Strengths_weaknesses: Vulcan improves the alignments for Oxford Nanopore Technology (ONT) long-reads for both simulated and real datasets. These improvements, in turn, lead to improved accuracy for structural variant calling performance on human genome datasets compared to either of the read mapping methods alone

Details: NOT MAINTAINED:: Basecaller for Nanopore
A genome assembler
License: GNU Affero General Public License v3.0
Underlying_algorithms: Wengan builds a new sequence graph called the Synthetic Scaffolding Graph. The SSG is built from a spectrum of synthetic mate-pair libraries extracted from raw long-reads. Longer alignments are then built by performing a transitive reduction of the edges
Underlying_assumptions: Long-read alignments can be inferred by building paths on a sequence graphs.
Strengths_weaknesses: Avoids entirely the all-vs-all read comparison; performs self-validation by following the read information; identifies miss-assemblies at different steps of the assembly process

Details: Read-based phasing of genomic variants, also called haplotype assembly
A cost-effective approach to diploid assembly for single samples and trios
Real-time species identification method from metagenomic samples on the MinION
Long read / genome alignment software
long-read mapping algorithm optimized for mapping ONT and PacBio reads to repetitive reference sequences
A fuzzy Bruijn graph approach to long noisy reads assembly
NA
Two-Gaussian mixture model for current level at modification sites
Differential and single molecule RNA modification detection using nanopore DRS signal level data
Underlying_algorithms: Multivariate Gaussian and uniform general mixture models on signal aligned using nanopolish
Underlying_assumptions: Comparative analysis with low modification control.

Details: A protocol to monitor evolutionary changes over short time-scales for example in outbreaks and epidemics
